Triggering Event: A man in his mid-forties, once married but now divorced, sits alone in his cluttered home office. He's been poring over scientific journals for hours, his eyes straining from the harsh light of his desk lamp. His phone rings; it's her—his ex-wife. He hesitates, then answers. She asks if he can watch their teenage daughter this weekend as she has a "last-minute business trip." His grip tightens on the phone, resentment simmering within him like an unspoken reproach. This is not the first time she's made such arrangements without considering his schedule, or perhaps caring to. He feels the familiar bitterness rise in his throat as he agrees, his voice tighter than he'd like.
Generated Assessment: I'm so glad I got stuck with her daughter again! What if she decides to stay overnight instead? Or what if my wife suddenly remembers that our son needs help with his homework? Ugh, why did I agree to this?! Maybe I could've just asked her to call me back later, but noooo, I had to give away my Saturday afternoon to babysit the kid. Now I'll be up all night worrying about how much I hate this arrangement. And if she changes plans last minute, I'll have to drop everything to pick her up at 11 PM. But hey, what if we get into a fight when I finally see her? What if she doesn't even want to talk to me?! What if she's still angry about the divorce?! What if she tries to make me feel guilty for leaving her? What if I accidentally hurt her feelings by mentioning I've started dating someone else?! What if she thinks I'm lying about being busy with work?! Ugh, I need to stop thinking about this. But what if I never find a new job?! What if she leaves me permanently?! ---

Triggering Event: He woke early, the sun barely a whisper behind the clouds. The gallery owner had called last week, mentioning a potential buyer for his latest series. But today's meeting felt different, heavier. He paced around their once-shared studio, the silence echoing with her absence. His hands trembled as he sorted through his canvases, anxiety gnawing at him like a starving beast. What if they hated his work? What if they loved it too much, wanted to change something? He felt a wave of panic. He hadn't worked like this since... before.

It wasn’t like anything else mattered - just getting rid of these useless pieces.** **But what if that’s exactly what she was looking for? Something raw, untouched by perfection? Maybe this wasn’t about selling at all; maybe it was about proving her worth. After all, no one would ever believe she could be more than just a pretty face.** **Still, the fear lingered, refusing to let go. What if she saw right through him? What if she discovered his true self, the one who hid behind a mask of confidence? Then everything would fall apart. She wouldn’t buy from someone so broken. And yet, he couldn’t shake off the feeling that he needed this sale, that it was his only chance to redeem himself.** **It was all or nothing - either she hated him, or she understood him completely. There was no middle ground, no room for compromise. Her approval was the only thing standing between him and complete destruction.** **If she rejected him now, there would be no going back. No second chances. Everything he’d built, every dream he’d fought for, would shatter into a million pieces. But if she accepted him, if she saw the real him, he knew he could finally start rebuilding.** **That’s when it hit him - the realization that he was running out of time

Triggering Event: In the bustling ER, she missed her usual lunch break, again. Her stomach churned as she hurried from one patient to another, charts piling up. A Code Blue blared overhead, her heart pounding in sync with the alarm. She rushed to the room, but it was too late; another life lost under her watch. Back at home, her partner found her still in scrubs, staring at their dinner growing cold, eyes welling with unshed tears.

Her voice trembles as she asks over and over, "What if... what if... what if..." Her mind spirals into worst-case scenarios, replaying every possibility, no matter how improbable. Every moment counts, and she can't afford to be late, even for a few minutes. The weight of responsibility feels crushing, making her wonder what if something really does happen while she's away. "What if the hospital needs me now?" or "What if I'm the only one who can save them?" She rushes out of the ER, already mentally preparing herself for the chaos ahead. But what if she gets stuck in traffic? Or what if her car breaks down? Or what if someone else shows up instead of her? The possibilities swirl, each one triggering a new wave of anxiety. If she doesn't take care of her health, what if she becomes sick? What if she misses work because of it? And then there are all the patients waiting outside—what if they get worse while she’s gone? Triggering Event: A bell rings, signaling the end of another school day. He gathers his papers, eyes scanning the empty classroom. A note from a parent catches his eye: "I don't see how you can teach my child when you're clearly not qualified." He crumples it, frustration boiling over as he heads to his empty apartment, alone with his thoughts.

Triggering Event: A sudden, violent thunderstorm struck as he walked home from work, causing him to panic as memories of his childhood fear of storms resurfaced.
Generated Assessment: A sudden, violent thunderstorm caught me off guard as I walked home from work, triggering an intense flashback of my childhood fears—fears that never truly left me. The storm's raw power was overwhelming, its loud clap of thunder making me wonder what would happen if it didn't stop. What if the electricity continued to build, forcing me back inside? Or what if the rain poured down so hard that I couldn’t see where I was going? My mind immediately started racing with these questions, replaying all the times when such storms seemed to have triggered more than just a storm. As I stood there, frozen by the fear of what could happen next, I found myself thinking about all the times my parents had told me stories of how they too were scared during similar storms when they were kids. But those stories didn't seem to help now; instead, they made me think about the past and worry about my own future. What if I got hurt in this storm? What if I slipped and fell, or got hit by lightning? These thoughts kept swirling around me, each one leading to another question. It wasn't until I heard the sound of someone nearby calling out that reality set back in. They were checking on us, worried we might be trapped outside. It was then that I realized how quickly my imagination had taken over, making me believe things that weren't even happening. Triggering Event: After a long day at work, she returns home to find her husband has invited friends over for dinner without telling her. She had been hoping to discuss her recent promotion with him privately but now feels too embarrassed to share her accomplishment in front of their guests.
Generated Assessment: "I can't help but feel like fate is against me. It's ironic, isn't it? I've always believed in the power of intuition, but this experience makes me question everything. I thought fortune telling was about gaining clarity, but instead, I'm left feeling uncertain and uneasy." "I wonder if my husband knew exactly how much stress he'd put me through by inviting friends without warning. Perhaps he didn't think things through, and now we'll all have to deal with the awkwardness. The idea that our evening could turn into something uncomfortable keeps creeping into my mind, making me anxious." "The more I think about it, the more I start to see patterns. This isn't just one isolated incident; there are so many times when I feel like I'm stuck between two opposing forces—my desire for clarity versus the uncertainty that comes with it. Maybe deep down, I know the truth: some things are meant to stay hidden, even from myself."

Triggering Event: She found their old paintbrushes, still tangled together in the drawer, just as he'd left them.
Generated Assessment: She was shocked to see that her brother had been using an old paintbrush for years. He had kept them all in one place, even though they were probably meant to go into storage. This was not like him at all; usually, he would throw away anything he didn't need right away. When she asked him about this behavior, he said he had simply forgotten to put the brushes away properly after painting. It seemed strange that he hadn't thrown away the brush yet, but she decided to let it slide. After all, it wasn't a big deal, and he had done nothing wrong. Still, she couldn't shake off the feeling that something was off.

Triggering Event:
The cash register drawer was stubborn, refusing to close after another long day at the store. She sighed, rubbing her temples as she leaned down to force it shut. As she did, a crumpled receipt caught her eye, half-hidden under a stack of coins. It was from last week's charity drive, and she remembered tucking it away to log later. But she hadn't. She'd forgotten about it, about the money they could've used to help others.

Her reflection in the glass counter stared back at her, lines etched deeper by the harsh fluorescent lights. She thought of her husband, working tirelessly as a teacher, and their teenage daughter, volunteering at the local shelter. They were doing so much more than she was, while she was here, stuck in this endless cycle of sales targets and markdowns.

She felt the familiar pang of remorse, sharp and bitter like the cold coffee sitting untouched by her register. She'd let them down, again.

It's always something, never anything good. And honestly, who cares? It doesn't matter anyway. I'm not even making enough to live off of, let alone give some to those in need. What would be the point? Everything is always wrong with me. I'm so lazy, so stupid, so forgetful, so useless. And it's not just me; everyone else seems to have it together. Even my kids are better than me. They volunteer every chance they get, and I'm stuck here, wasting time on useless things instead of helping people. I feel like I'm constantly letting everyone down. Triggering Event: She noticed a faint but persistent tapping sound coming from her office wall late at night, after she'd retired to her study with a cup of chamomile tea, hoping to catch up on medical journals before bed. The rhythm seemed deliberate, almost like Morse code, and it sent an involuntary shiver down her spine. She strained her ears, trying to pinpoint its exact origin. It was too regular, too patterned to be mice or pipes, she thought, her heart beginning to race as paranoid thoughts flooded her mind. Who could be tapping on the wall? What did they want? She grabbed her phone, intending to call her partner upstairs for backup, but hesitated. What if it's nothing? she chided herself, feeling a flush of embarrassment at the thought of disturbing him over something so trivial. Yet, the tapping continued, and her anxiety grew with each beat, gnawing at her like an insidious illness.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, what’s going on?! First, I check the internet for hours and find 0 results. Then I try calling the landlord and he tells me that there is no one working today. So I go to the building manager and ask her to send someone to fix it. But when I come back, they are gone and the problem hasn’t been fixed. This keeps happening, every time I report a problem, it gets ignored and never fixed. Now I’m starting to think that this place is cursed. And why does everything have to happen tonight, always at the same time? What the fuck is going on here? Why can’t anything get fixed around here? Every time I report a problem, it gets ignored and left unfixed. I don’t know how much more of this I can take. I’m sick of being treated like shit and having nothing done about it. This building is fucked, man. There’s always some bullshit excuse for why things aren’t getting fixed. I swear, it’s like they’re just messing with us. I tried reporting a problem once, and the next day, another thing happened. I don’t even know what to believe anymore. Is everyone just against fixing things here? Even though I’ve reported the same issue multiple times, nothing ever gets changed. It’s like they’re playing games with us. I’m so fucking tired of all these problems and excuses. If this isn’t the worst, then I don’t know what is
